paragraphs.text:
%md
### Doing ETL with Spark
1. It is typical to not have all the data you want.
2. It can also sometimes be painful to work with the available data you have (in this case, xml parsed to json)
3. We will look at how to extract the data we need from the available resources (`books_detailed_etl_large.json`)

msg.data:
Doing ETL with Spark

  1. It is typical to not have all the data you want.
  2. It can also sometimes be painful to work with the available data you have (in this case, xml parsed to json)
  3. We will look at how to extract the data we need from the available resources (books_detailed_etl_large.json)

paragraphs.title: Import the Books Detailed DataSet
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import spark.implicits._
import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._

val bookDetailsDf = spark.read.option("inferSchema", "true").json("/odsc/books_detailed_etl_large.json")
bookDetailsDf.printSchema
bookDetailsDf.createOrReplaceTempView("details")

paragraphs.title: Use Spark Dataset to make working with Data Easier
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import spark.implicits._
import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._
/*
 Help with future work by creating a Datasets. Dataset's require a Type. Given scala CaseClasses's extend scala Product, we can easily create types like we see below
*/
case class Author(id: Long, name: String, role: String, ratingsCount: Long, textReviewsCount: Long, averageRating: Double)
case class Genre(name: String, count: Long)
case class Book(
    id: Long,
    title: String,
    isEbook: Boolean,
    isbn: String,
    isbn13: String,
    languageCode: String,
    numPages: Long,
    publicationYear: Long,
    publicationMonth: Long,
    publicationDay: Long,
    publisher: String,
    ratingsCount: Long,
    ratingsDist: String,
    genres: Seq[Genre],
    authors: Seq[Author]
)

case class BookToAuthor(
    authorBookId: Long,
    authorId: Long,
    authorName: String,
    authorAverageRating: Double,
    authorRatingsCount: Long,
    authorReviewsCount: Long
    )

case class BookToGenre(
    genreBookId: Long,
    genreName: String,
    userTaggedCount: Long
    )


implicit val bookEncoder = Encoders.product[Book]
implicit val authorEncoder = Encoders.product[Author]
implicit val genreEncoder = Encoders.product[Genre]
implicit val bookAuthorEncoder = Encoders.product[BookToAuthor]
implicit val bookGenreEncoder = Encoders.product[BookToGenre]
val books: Dataset[Book] = bookDetailsDf.drop("_corrupt_record").where(col("id").isNotNull).as[Book]
books.createOrReplaceTempView("book_details")

paragraphs.title: Create Authors Index
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val bookIdToAuthor = books.flatMap { b =>
 val bookId = b.id
 val mainAuthor = b.authors.filter { a => a.role == "author" }.headOption
 mainAuthor match {
   case Some(author) =>
     Some(BookToAuthor(bookId, author.id, author.name, author.averageRating, author.ratingsCount, author.textReviewsCount))
   case None => None
 }
}
bookIdToAuthor.printSchema
bookIdToAuthor.show(10)
bookIdToAuthor.createOrReplaceTempView("book_authors")

paragraphs.title: Look at the Authors. What can we learn from this data?
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select authorName, max(authorAverageRating) as authorAverageRating from book_authors group by authorName order by authorAverageRating desc

paragraphs.title: Generate Popular Genres list
paragraphs.text:
%spark
val popularGenres = genres
  .groupBy("genreName")
  .agg(
      sum(col("userTaggedCount")) as "userTagged"
   )
   .sort(desc("userTagged"))

popularGenres.createOrReplaceTempView("genres_ranked")
//select genreName, sum(userTaggedCount) as userTagged from book_genres group by genreName order by userTagged desc

paragraphs.title: Join the Authors on Genres.
paragraphs.text:
%spark
// join authors to genres by bookId
val authorsAndGenres = genres
  .join(bookIdToAuthor)
  .where($"genreBookId" === $"authorBookId")
  .drop("authorBookId")
  .withColumnRenamed("genreBookId", "bookId")

authorsAndGenres.createOrReplaceTempView("author_genres")

paragraphs.title: Save our Work for Next Step

paragraphs.text:
%md
### What Now?
1. Take the book_authors, book_genres and author_genres and store them for later as parquet data
2. This will be the basis of how we start to recommend new Books to users
3. In the next section we will create an Honest Ranking of Authors, Books in Top Genres, and introduce our User

Up Next: [5-SparkML-Unsupervised](http://localhost:8080/#/notebook/2EQKQP1CV)
